title: 104_hr1541
content: The Act titled "Iran Foreign Sanctions Act of 1995" imposes sanctions on persons engaging in trade with Iran. The President will impose sanctions on foreign persons trading with Iran in goods or technology if determined in writing. Sanctions apply to the foreign person, any successor entity, and parent or subsidiary entities. Sanctions will be imposed on foreign persons trading with Iran in goods or technology, including parent or subsidiary entities with requisite knowledge engaged in the activities. The sanctions include a procurement sanction where the US Government cannot procure goods or services from the sanctioned entities. The US Government is prohibited from procuring goods or services from certain sanctioned entities, and export and import sanctions are imposed on these entities. There are exceptions for defense articles or services under existing contracts. The President may exempt certain entities from sanctions if they are sole source suppliers of defense articles or services deemed essential for national security. The President may exempt certain entities from sanctions if they are sole source suppliers of defense articles or services essential to national security under defense coproduction agreements, contracts entered into before the President's intention to impose sanctions, spare parts, component parts essential to US products, routine servicing and maintenance, and information and technology essential to national security. The President may exempt certain entities from sanctions if they are sole source suppliers of defense articles or services essential to national security. This provision supersedes existing law related to Iran under the Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992. SEC. 3. WAIVER AUTHORITY. The President can waive the provisions if Iran meets certain conditions regarding human rights, nuclear weapons, and terrorism support. SEC. 4. REPORT REQUIRED. The President must provide regular reports on Iran's military capabilities and support for terrorism. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "act of international terrorism" in this Act refers to violent acts that violate US laws and are intended to intimidate civilians, influence government policies, or affect government conduct through coercion, assassination, or kidnapping. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. A "foreign person" is defined as an individual who is not a US national or a non-US entity. "Iran" includes any agency or instrumentality of Iran. A "nuclear explosive device" is any device, assembled or disassembled. A "device" is any device designed to release nuclear energy greater than one pound of TNT. "Requisite knowledge" refers to knowing as defined in the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. "State" includes various territories and possessions of the United States. The term "United States" includes several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, and any other territory or possession of the United States. The term "United States national" refers to a natural person who is a citizen of the United States, a corporation organized under U.S. laws, or a legal entity from a U.S. state, territory, or the District of Columbia. The term "United States" includes various territories and possessions. A legal entity is considered a U.S. entity if U.S. nationals own more than 50% of its capital stock. This also applies to foreign subsidiaries of such entities.
